questions.question: Why is it important to have a separate 'save_tasks' function?

options.text: It keeps the main loop clean and reusable
Python requires it for file safety
It prevents duplication of code every time a task is added or deleted

questions.explanation: Separating logic into functions (Modularization) makes your code easier to maintain and prevents repeating the same logic.

questions.question: Which mode is best for 'save_tasks' if you are overwriting the whole list with the new state?
questions.explanation: When saving a full list state, 'w' (write) mode is used to clear the old file content and start fresh with the current list.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'if __name__ == "__main__":' line?

options.text: It checks if the computer is on
It ensures the script only runs if executed directly, not if imported as a module
It creates a new user profile

questions.explanation: This is a common Python pattern that allows you to write code that can be both imported as a library and run as a standalone script.

questions.question: In the provided starter code, what happens if 'tasks.txt' does not exist yet?

options.text: The load_tasks function returns an empty list
Python creates a blank file immediately

questions.explanation: The try...except block in load_tasks catches the FileNotFoundError and returns an empty list instead of crashing.
